'''Bereket''', formerly '''Gazandjyk''' or ''Kazandzhik'' ({{lang-ru|'''Казанджик'''}} or {{lang|ru|Газанджык}} gɑˈzɑnd͡ʒik), is a [[List of cities in Turkmenistan|city]] in [[Balkan Province]] in western [[Turkmenistan]]. Bereket is the administrative centre of the [[Bereket District]].
The city is located in an oasis in the foothills of the [[Kopetdag|Kopetdag Mountains]] and on the edge of the [[Karakum Desert]].
Bereket is an important strategic [[Bereket railway station (Turkmenistan)|railway intersection]] of the [[Trans-Caspian Railway]] ([[Caspian Sea]]-[[Turkmenistan]]-[[Uzbekistan]]-[[Kazakhstan]]) and [[North–South Transport Corridor|North-South Transnational Railway]] ([[Russia]]-Kazakhstan-Turkmenistan-[[Iran]]-[[Persian Gulf]].<ref name="railway-technology1">{{cite web |url=http://www.railway-technology.com/projects/northsouthtransnatio/ |title=North-South Transnational Corridor |publisher=railway-technology.com|date= |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref><ref name="info">{{cite web |url=http://www.turkmenistaninfo.ru/?page_id=6&type=article&elem_id=page_6/magazine_114/1011&lang_id=en |title=Crossing of Railways |publisher=turkmenistaninfo.ru|date= |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>
The city has a large locomotive repair depot and a modern railway station.
The city is located approximately {{convert|260|km|0|abbr=on}} west of the Turkmen capital of [[Ashgabat]] and {{convert|340|km|0|abbr=on}} east of the [[Caspian Sea]] port of [[Türkmenbaşy, Turkmenistan|Turkmenbashi]]. The largest cities nearby are [[Balkanabat]] {{convert|120|km|0|abbr=on}} to the west, and [[Serdar (city)|Serdar]] {{convert|90|km|0|abbr=on}} to the east.
The estimated population of the city is 24,500 as of March 2015.
== Etymology == The exact origin of the name is unknown. ''Gazanjyk'' is probably derived from a [[Turkic language]] word ''gazan'' or ''kazan'' (meaning a large [[Kazan (cookware)|cooking pot used throughout Central Asia]], roughly equivalent to a [[cauldron]], boiler) and ''-jyk'' a suffix to denote ''small'' in size. The name can be translated into English as ''small kazan'' or ''small cauldron''. The present-day name of the city ''Bereket'' in the [[Turkmen language]] means ''abundance'' or ''prosperity''. The word ''Bereket'' is borrowed from the [[Persian language|Persian]] word ''Barakat'' (برکت) into Turkmen. Persian in turn has borrowed it from Arabic ''Barakah'' (برکة).
== History == Since ancient times the area where city is now located was known as an important junction on the famous [[Silk Road]] that connected [[China]] with the [[Middle East]] and [[Europe]].
[[Aleksey Kuropatkin]], the [[Imperial Russian Army]] commander of the Turkestan Rifle Brigade, who made an 18-day march in 1880–1881 across {{convert|500|mi|km|order=flip}} of Karakum desert writes in his memoirs "the 5th transition to Kazandjik – {{convert|64|mi|km|disp=sqbr}}. A waterless road. The soil is sandy, clayey, alkaline; there are sparse clumps of weeds and even sparser haloxylon trees four feet in height. This transition separates the Balkan mountains from Kyurendag. Kazandjik wells lie in the gorge of the Kyurendag mountains, along the stream of a small river. Water in the wells is fresh and of good quality."<ref name="voslit">{{cite web |url=http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/Dokumenty/M.Asien/XIX/1880-1900/Kuropatkin/text1.htm |title=Завоевание Туркмении. Поход в Ахал-теке в 1880–1881 гг. (Conquest of Turkmenija. Military campaign in Ahal-teke in 1880–1881. |publisher=vostlit.info|date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}}</ref>
After the conquest of the [[Transcaspian Oblast]] the [[Russian Empire]] started to build the [[Trans-Caspian railway]] including towns and settlements along the route. Kazandjik, as an urban city, was founded in 1895 to serve as an important junction on the railway.<ref name="acad">{{cite web |url=http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/bse/92111/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%BA |title=Большая советская энциклопедия (Large Soviet Encyclopedae) |publisher=|date= |accessdate=2014-02-02}}</ref>
In 1916–1942 Kazandjik and the area around the town was the scene of furious battles between Russian Imperial forces, and after 1918 Soviet Red Army, with local nationalist Muslims, during the [[Basmachi movement]].<ref name="max">{{cite web |url=http://maxpark.com/community/14/content/2324925 |title=Бои в пустыне. Туркмения. (Battles in the desert. Turkmenija.) |publisher=maxpark.com|date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}}</ref><ref name="konf">{{cite web |url=http://konftext.ru/1855.html |title=О боях за Казанджик. (Battles for Kazandjik.) |publisher=konftext.ru/|date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}}</ref>
During Soviet period the 61631th army garrison had been built on the outskirts of the city. In 1988 it had stationed strong army units, the 231th tank regiment, the 160th motorized rifle regiment and the 405th artillery regiment.<ref name="army">{{cite web |url=http://svaku.ru/forum/archive/index.php/t-755.html |title=Archive forum |publisher=svaku.ru|date= |accessdate=2016-04-08}}</ref>
The December [[2000 Turkmenistan earthquake]] (7.0 on the moment magnitude scale) devastated the city center.<ref name="trend">{{cite web |url=http://www.trend.az/news/politics/1465654.html |title=Президент Туркменистана дал поручение о благоустройстве города Берекет, пострадавшего от землетрясения 2000 года |publisher=trend.az|date= |accessdate=2009-05-05}}</ref>
==Geography== [[File:Kopetdag mountains in early spring, a view from Bereket city.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Kopetdag|Kopetdag mountains]] in early spring, a view from Bereket city.]] See satellite image of Bereket.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bing.com/maps/?v=2&cp=qj75msnmt46t&lvl=15&dir=0&sty=b&form=LMLTCC |title=Bing Kaarten – Routebeschrijvingen, verkeer en wegomstandigheden |publisher=Bing.com |date=2014-03-18 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>
The city is located on the most western foothills of the [[Kopetdag|Kopetdag mountains]] called [[Kyurendag Ridge|Kyurendag]] on the edge of the [[Karakum Desert|Karakum deserts]]. The maximum height of the Kyurendag ridge is {{convert|968|m|0|abbr=on}}. The vegetation of the ridge is quite poor and is represented primarily by species of desert flora, [[sagebrush]], semi-desert and dry [[steppe]] and rocky outcrops. Soils – gray soils. One can occasionally find [[Juniper|juniper trees]], single or large groups of ''tamarisk'' and small shrubs. Wildlife in recent years has become greatly impoverished. Ungulates are few in number. ''Argali'' sheep are seen occasionally, as are [[goat|bezoar goats]] and [[boar|wild boars]], [[gazelle]]s. Predators include[[wolves]], [[jackals]], [[foxes]], [[hyenas]]. Among birds klik are rarely seen and stone curlews and jacks very rarely. Reptile species are represented by the steppe tortoise, monitor lizard, boa, agam, etc.<ref name="restinwold">{{cite web |url=http://restinworld.ru/stories/turkmenistan/41079/1.html |title=Кюрендаг – горный хребет Туркменистана (Kyurendag – a mountain ridge in Turkmenistan) |publisher=restinworld.ru/|date= |accessdate=2014-03-11}}</ref>
The major source of water for irrigation is the [[Karakum Canal]].
==Demographics== The city is divided into several ''aul'' – neighborhoods. The majority of the inhabitants are [[Turkmen people|Turkmen]] from the [[Yomud]] tribes, with a minority of [[Teke tribe|Teke]]. Previously strong communities of Azeris, Armenians, Russians, Ukrainians and Persians are now reduced to several families. In the 1990s most of them migrated to larger cities for better economic opportunities. Many Russian families also emigrated to the [[Russian Federation]].
==Economy== The city is the semi-industrial and semi-agricultural centre of the Bereket District. It is an important railway and automobile junction,<ref name="gazette">{{cite web |url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/infrastructure/single-view/view/presidents-open-kazakhstan-to-turkmenistan-rail-link.html |title=Presidents open Kazakhstan to Turkmenistan rail link |publisher=Railwaygazette.com|date= |accessdate=2013-05-13}}</ref> the city has a large [[railroad yard]] and [[Motive power depot|locomotive repair depot]], a brick production factory, [[Turkmen carpet]] [[weaving]] factory, wheat and cotton processing and storage facilities. Animal breeding (camels, cows, sheep) is another source of income.
In September 2014 a poultry complex with production capacity of 8 million eggs and 1000 tons of poultry meat a year was constructed.<ref name="gazette-2">{{cite web |url=http://www.turkmenistan.gov.tm/?id=7324 |title=Новый птицекомплекс |publisher=turkmenistan.gov.tm|date= |accessdate=2013-10-01}}</ref>
== Finance == The State Commercial Bank ''Dayhanbank'' has its branch office in Bereket.<ref name="dayhan">{{cite web|url=http://www.dayhanbank.gov.tm/bank_barada/sahamca/|title=Şahamçalarymyz (Branch offices)|publisher=dayhanbank.gov.tm|accessdate=2014-03-10|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310154317/http://www.dayhanbank.gov.tm/bank_barada/sahamca/|archivedate=2014-03-10}}</ref>
== Communication == The postal area code for the city is 745130.<ref name="post">{{cite web|url=http://www.turkmenpost.gov.tm/about_index.php|title=Türkmenpoçta Poçta aragatnaşygy döwlet kompaniýasynyň aragatnaşyk bölümleriniň indexleri|publisher=turkmenpost.gov.tm|accessdate=2014-03-10|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130913155726/http://www.turkmenpost.gov.tm/about_index.php|archivedate=2013-09-13}}</ref> The city has a stable mobile coverage by two mobile communication operators, the state-owned [[Altyn Asyr]] and Russian-owned [[MTS Turkmenistan]].
== City and national transportation == [[File:Un-turkmenistan.png|thumb|right|300px|Bereket is an important railway junction on the [[Railways in Turkmenistan|Turkmenistan national railway system]].]] [[File:M37 Turkmenistan-en.png|thumb|right|300px|Bereket is located on the [[M37 highway (Turkmenistan)|M37 Highway]], Turkmenistan section.]] The city has a small public transportation network. Several small buses run scheduled routes connecting the eastern and western parts of the city (some 5–6 km.)
Bereket is an important railway junction and station for commercial and freight transportation on the [[Railways in Turkmenistan|Turkmenistan national railway system]].
==Role in transnational transportation== Bereket city (''[[Kazandzhik]]'') is a strategically important railway crossing of the [[Trans-Caspian Railway]] ([[Caspian Sea]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Uzbekistan]] and eastern [[Kazakhstan]]) and North-South Transnational Railway ([[Russia]]-Kazakhstan-Turkmenistan-[[Iran]]-[[Persian Gulf]]). The city has a large locomotive repair depot and a modern passenger railway station.
The Kazakhstan-Turkmenistan-Iran railway link is a part of the [[North–South Transport Corridor]] and is a {{convert|677|km|0|abbr=on}} long railway line connecting Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan with Iran and the [[Persian Gulf]]. It links [[Zhanaozen|Uzen]] in Kazakhstan with Bereket – [[Gyzyletrek|Etrek]] in Turkmenistan and ends at [[Gorgan]] in Iran's Golestan province. In Iran, the railway will be linked to the national network making its way to the ports of the Persian Gulf.<ref name="railway-technology1"/> The project is estimated to cost $620m which is being jointly funded by the governments of Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Iran.<ref name="railway-technology1"/>
In May 2013, the {{convert|311|km|0|abbr=on}} Bereket – Uzen section of the [[North–South Transport Corridor|North-South Transnational Railway]] was completed.<ref name="gazette"/><ref name="gazette2">{{cite web |url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/single-view/view/news-in-brief-52.html?sword_list%5B%5D=Bereket&no_cache=1 |title=Caspian rail corridor funds agreed |publisher=Railwaygazette.com|date= |accessdate=2010-02-23}}</ref> In February 2014 {{convert|256|km|0|abbr=on}} long section between Bereket and [[Gyzyletrek|Etrek]] was completed. Currently railway stations along the new railway are being constructed such as [[Däneata]], [[Dövletýar]], [[Bugdaýly]], [[Balguýi]], [[Madaw]], [[Akjadepe]].<ref name="business">{{cite web |url=http://www.turkmenbusiness.org/news/zaversheno-stroitelstvo-uchastka-bereket-etrek-magistrali-kazakhstan%E2%80%93turkmenistan%E2%80%93iran |title=Завершено строительство участка Берекет – Этрек магистрали Казахстан–Туркменистан–Иран |publisher=Turkmen Business |date= |accessdate=2014-03-27}}</ref> <ref name="pres">{{cite web |url=http://www.turkmenistan.gov.tm/_eng/?id=2616 |title=President of Turkmenistan visits the construction site of Bereket-Etrek section of the North-South railway |publisher=turkmenistan.gov.tm |date=2013-08-21 |accessdate=2014-03-27}}</ref>
The Kazakhstan-Turkmenistan-Iran railway link was be officially inaugurated in October 2014.<ref name="zaw">{{cite web |url=http://www.zawya.com/story/IranTurkmenistanKazakhstan_railway_to_come_on_stream_in_6_months-ZAWYA20140228064818/ |title=Iran-Turkmenistan-Kazakhstan railway to come on stream in 6 months |publisher=Zawya.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>
The city is located on the [[M37 highway (Turkmenistan)|M37 Highway]] (Turkmenistan's section of the [[European route E60]] which connects [[Brest, France]] to [[Irkeshtam]], [[Kyrgyzstan]] on the border with the [[People's Republic of China]]).
==Education, health, culture == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Secondary school No.26 in Bereket city.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Secondary school No.26 in Bereket.]] --> The city has three public schools, kindergartens, a small hospital, and medical emergency centre.
In 2012 several new buildings were constructed within the State Development Program including the mayor's office (''[[hakimlik]]''), two schools, a hotel, cultural center, a hospital and a knitting factory.<ref name="tkmru">{{cite web |url=http://www.turkmenistan.ru/?page_id=3&lang_id=ru&elem_id=14898&type=event&sort=date_desc |title=Туркменский город Берекет будет преобразован |publisher=Turkmenistan.ru|date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}}</ref>
Until 2000, the city had a library, two open-air and one winter cinema. All are currently closed.
==Climate== Bereket has a [[desert climate]], with generally warm winters and very hot summers. Rainfall is generally light and erratic, and occurs mainly in the winter and autumn months. In summer, day temperatures may rise to 42–44 C', and during nights fall to 15–18 C'. The air flow is windy, chilly in winters and dusty in summers.

== Sightseeing == {{main|Bereket Railway Depot}} [[File:Russian loc T series type 132.jpg|thumb|right|350px|[[Bereket Railway Depot]] owns a Russian made class T locomotive ''ТЭ-189'' (built between 1857–1915).]]
In its storage area, the Bereket Depot museum, has a relic Russian made class T locomotive ''ТЭ-189'' (built between 1857–1915).
[[Russian locomotive class FD|FD class steam locomotives]] ''ФД20-2526, ФД20–2494 (ФД20–1441)'' (built between 1931–1942), and [[0-10-0|Russian class E locomotives]] ''Эр796-88, Эм734–66 (Эм733–96), Эу705–41, Эм725–30, Э-13'' (built between 1912–1957).<ref name="pereezd"/>
There are also several ''ТЭ1'' class locomotives, whose prototype was the famous [[US]] made [[ALCO RSD-1]] locomotive.<ref name="pereezd">{{cite web |url=http://pereyezd.ru/readarticle.php?article_id=81 |title=Репортаж из прошлого (Reportage from the Past) |publisher=Роман Молочников (Roman Molochnikov)|date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}}</ref>
== Bereket Railway Station == {{main|Bereket railway station (Turkmenistan)}} Bereket Railway Station ({{lang-tk|Bereket demirýol menzili}}) is the main railway station in the city. It was built in 1885. The station is operated by the [[Railways in Turkmenistan|Türkmendemirýollary]].
